metadata.name: Dashed Migration #33
metadata.description:
This is an ode to dashed lines and vector graphics.

The artwork is an animated SVG generated with Javascript.
All the animation is described and handled within the SVG.

Exports:
â€¢ animated SVG
â€¢ plotter-ready SVG
â€¢ PNG

Controls:
â€¢ 'SPACE'/click - play/pause animation
In Live view
â€¢ 'f' - fullscreen
â€¢ 'c' - show/hide cursor
â€¢ 'e' - open the export menu
On touchscreens, the export menu can be opened with a long-press.

fx(hash) Generative Token by loackme

metadata.name: Chaos Culture #263
metadata.description:
"Chaos Culture" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022.

ã€Šè¥¿éŠè¨˜ã€‹ç¬¬ä¸€å›ž:ã€Œæ··æ²Œæœªåˆ†å¤©åœ°äº‚ï¼ŒèŒ«èŒ«æ¸ºæ¸ºç„¡äººè¦‹ã€‚ã€

Chaos Culture is the final chapter of this series. There is a legend in the East that before Pan Gu opened up the sky and created the earth, the world was a chaotic place, and no one knew its appearance. And I have always been fascinated by this mythical story since he was a child.

These three works have a father-son relationship, Research > Memory > Culture, with each work re-growing through the remnants of the previous work, depending on its image. From the beginning of the creative coding, I like the concept of recursion the most. Here I experiment with my central thinking through this iterative relationship so that the work is not only the shadow of the artist but also the pulling force of repetition.

"æ··æ²Œ" Chaos in Eastern culture represents the initial state of things. This state is consistent with what we believe in generative art: Anything can happen if different forces are applied. Letting chaos grow out of order and then destroying it, the iterative process, is like my usual dialogue with myself, and maybe it's all just a diary.

Through these three series of works, whether I can eventually find everything in my childhood fantasy, I am not sure yet. The only thing I can be sure of is that I will continue to explore.

- Click the mouse to save an artwork.
- Collectors who own this NFT have the right to print the work.

Artist: Aluan Wang (ileivoivm).
Made with p5js and glsl.

metadata.name: Noisy Gardens #98
metadata.description:
I had a wonderful childhood. I grew up near a big lake, in a house with a huge garden. You could get lost for the whole day, building houses on trees, collecting flowers and stones or stealing food from the vegetable garden. Having a brother of the same age made things even better, endless adventures with somebody saving you every time you are too dumb to realize you are walking into troubles.

We enjoyed the summers with the hot days, the fireflies and the nights full of falling stars. The winters with the snow, the stalactites and our box turtle disappearing for months to then reappear in the spring (Until she did not).

At the same time, taking care of the garden was a big responsibility, affecting our family life in many ways. Numerous times, I felt like the efforts we were putting in to keep it in order were never enough and nature was always faster in restoring her point of view. A struggle that affects us humans since we started to bend nature at our will, thousands of years ago.

In my gardens, I tried to capture this struggle, this constant fight to shape nature at our will.
However, I also tried to represent the beauty that can be found in both savage and human shaped nature, if shaped with love and respect.

I dedicate this project to my grandfather, who gave us a garden.
I am sure he would have loved it.

---

Hand coded with love and obsession. ðŸ’š

Powered by p5, p5.createLoop and chroma.

======> COMMANDS (In Live Mode) <======

Press â€˜sâ€™ to save the current output.
Press â€˜mâ€™ to open a menu with the available outputs.

The generation of a hi-res image, up to 8000x8000, takes a few seconds.
The generation of an Animated GIF takes several minutes and the save command works only once the GIF is complete.

Settings are passed as URL parameters that can be used to load different configurations.

- mode = 0 | 1
0 For static PNG images, 1 for animated GIFs

- size = s | m | l
The Size of the output, 1080x1080, 4000x4000, 8000x8000 for static images and 512x512, 800x800, 1080x1080 for animated GIFs

- fps = 10 | 15 | 20 | 25 | 30
Frames per second of animated GIFs

metadata.name: Trust #10
metadata.description:
Trust is an abstraction of the creative process, finding the line just before form becomes texture. Your experience with the painting requires trust; trust that something will appear from the chaos of the empty space, trust that the composition you imagine halfway through will evolve along with your ideas, and trust that the etchings lend a helping hand to the message of the piece. You may find yourself pulled left and right when decisions are made, and your interpretation at 25%, 50%, and 90% will all differ. This is what makes creating so fulfilling to me, a work of art can change course wildly from start to finish, ever molding itself until it enters the kiln.

Press â€˜1â€™, â€˜2â€™, or  â€˜3â€™ to increase resolution (default is 1, higher than default may not work on certain browsers. Successfully testing in Chrome, Brave, and Opera GX with hardware acceleration enabled)

Click or tap to zoom to full res (exact zoom depends on your display)
Press â€™sâ€™ to save a .png
Press â€™tâ€™ to toggle brush texture

Created with p5.js and chroma.js

metadata.name: Ailerons #125
metadata.description:
Ailerons, littering the factory floor, custom made and ready to be fitted to their respective aircraft. An accent trickles across the canvas, coloring any object in its path.

A study of light, built entirely in a 2d renderer, creating light and shadow with math and logic.

Press 's' to save a .png

Created with p5.js and chroma.js

metadata.name: In a Moment, a Thousand Years #104
metadata.description:
Fragmented time and fractured memories.

=========

Controls:

[1] set resolution to 716 x 1024px (default)
[2] set resolution to 1433 x 2048px
[3] set resolution to 2455 x 3508px (approx. the size of A4 paper)
[4] set resolution to 3472 x 4961px (approx. the size of A3 paper)
[5] set resolution to 4911 x 7016px (approx. the size of A2 paper)

[0] set resolution to current window size

[c] capture a screenshot at rendered resolution

*The higher resolution settings (3-5) can slow down your device, especially on a low-end laptop without a dedicated GPU. Use it only to render and download a hi-res output for printing. For screen viewing [1] or [2] is recommended.



Made with cables.gl, a node-based webgl environment

XALTED 2022

metadata.name: Imperium #84
metadata.description:
Imperium is a study of shapes and colors, and how a very small set of shapes and colors, when given equally simple rules, can create a great variety of patterns that may bring meaning to the viewer.

Press the s key for a quick download at the current resolution, and press the space bar to display the export and information menu.

For more information, read the collection guide:
https://medium.com/@MrMallory/imperium-the-collection-guide-cd9ab7e05aa0

Author:
Mr. Mallory (https://twitter.com/MrMallory_)

metadata.name: Ersbla #253
metadata.description:
Ersbla is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022. 

It is the third entry in a series of abstract generative experiments inspired by the graphic and textile work of Anni and Josef Albers. As a follow-up to the 'Sabler' and 'Lebras' collections, 'Ersbla' produces textile effects using a combination of thousands of tiny dots arranged on variable grids, resulting in a wide variety of unique Bauhaus-inspired compositions in a variety of palettes.

Press 'S' to save a high-resolution 2400 x 3396 px image in PNG format.

Depending on the density of your output, please allow up to a few seconds for your edition to generate.

metadata.name: Glossolalia #8
metadata.description:
This series is ultimately about catharsis. The compositions can be chaotic and maybe even a little messy, but they also can be vibrant and diverseâ€¦ which is really what this is trying to celebrate: diversity and expression.

Simply, itâ€™s about the emotions associated with whatever frees you.

Please see the linked fxtext article (on the main project page) for a more in-depth dissection of the concept. Itâ€™s less of a technical discussion, and more about the experience of the artist, and how it became linked with the feelings they associate with the art.

In live mode:

For higher resolutions, you can append â€œ&density=2â€ to the url to double the size, â€œ&density=3â€ to triple, and so on.
(This is highly recommended.)

To adjust grain, you can append â€œ&grain=##â€ to the url. 40 is the default, and 0 will remove it completely.

metadata.name: Artifact #10
metadata.description:
This project is about uncovering artifacts.

Each piece is determined by approximately 15 parameters. This allows for a multitude of possible forms, and each iteration is an artifact to be discovered within the multidimensional space.

This work is focused around discovery. It is about exploring the space of the algorithm, shedding light on its many forms, and sometimes finding artifacts of the real world embedded within them.

Technically, this work is a composition of three primary elements: Voronoi tessellations, orthographic projection, and the depth-sort algorithm.
The latter of these is integral to the rendering mechanism. It works intuitively, drawing distant objects before near objects, evaluating the distance of each object according to its geometric center. It does this precisely, and in doing so, it can produce interesting visual artifacts, drawing some shapes in an unexpected order.



This has been a fascinating study, bringing light to unreal shapes and forms, and uncovering artifacts in an impossible space.

I hope you enjoy it,
Nat Sarkissian





Technical Notes:
- Append â€œ&mag=Nâ€ to the end of the URL in live mode to specify a resolution multiplier. It will render the image N times larger than the size of your window. If you have specified anything greater than 1, a download will start automatically once the rendering is done.

metadata.name: Fuschia Aluminium Lilac #6
metadata.description:
"Fuschia Aluminium Lilac" is a p5.js project where isometric shapes are placed and have their size and color adjusted based on an underlying image taken from Adolphe Millot's "Fleurs". Each form gets its color and size from a particular pixel. Giving the isometric forms a slight wiggle provides the piece with a more painterly feel.

Adolphe Millot on Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolphe_Philippe_Millot

metadata.name: A Stroll through the Garden #112
metadata.description:
Exploring the medium, physical, digital, made with AI, is an endless and exciting walk through a garden full of discoveries and hidden corners.

The choice of linocut aesthetics is connected with the personal background as an artist who worked with graphic techniques, childhood memories and feelings of trees deprived of their leaves in winter.

Thanks to YulikolaY for getting the code ready for production.

Made with love, AI and p5.js code

January, 2023

metadata.name: For Algernon #152
metadata.description:
I brought flowers for Algernon, but some are lost to time
When logic gives way to emotions and order surrenders to entropy
For lost youths and forgotten dreams
Someday there may be flowers for me

This work is inspired by the brilliant short story Flowers for Algernon. I read the story for the first time last year, cried, then immediately started working on this series. The initial painting process cannot be paused; this is my intention and not an oversight. You may watch the perfect moment slip by, but I hope that youâ€™ll come to love the end result as well. There is beauty in imperfection, and everything that is remembered is not entirely lost. After the initial painting is complete, you can press [p] to watch it continuously evolve.

I developed two new original algorithms for this work. First, a method to draw flowers by rotating and layering sine waves at varying amplitudes and wavelengths to create a variety of colored petals. Second, a real-time painting method with multisampling to blend and generate new colors on the fly. The first method represents order, logic and the intellect, while the second represents entropy, chance, and emotions. Together, this is a study of generative flowers under entropy, where strokes are allowed to wander and colors to mix freely. I didnâ€™t set out to emulate any traditional media, but the outputs of this algorithm often resemble acrylic paintings at first glance. Upon closer inspection you will discover that each painting is entirely made of opaque geometric strokes that are distinctly digital. 

This work is best viewed in a Chrome or Edge browser on a desktop machine, where the initial painting process only takes a few seconds. The rendering in Safari and Firefox is significantly slower as of January 2023. Made with p5js and the canvas API.

Keyboard controls:
[p] Play/pause painting after the initial rendering is completed.
[f] Fill the current window (press â€˜fâ€™ again to get back to the original aspect ratio).
[g] Toggle the background texture.
[m] Change the margin amount. 
[s] Saves a PNG image of the live view, default resolution is 1600x2000px.
[1]-[6] Change the output resolution, up to 9600x12000px. 

URL parameters:
&aspect=[an aspect ratio between 0.25 and 4, default is 0.8]
&texture=[a roughness value greater than or equal to 0, default is 1]
&margin=[the amount of margin around the painting (try 20 to 150), default is 0]
&fill=[true/false, whether to fill the window]

Created by Elsif, 2023.01.

P.S. Someday I may no longer understand all the code I wrote, but there will always be an impression of colors, and a memory of flowers.

metadata.name: bots..inc. #2
metadata.description:
Art can sometimes create strong emotions.
It's like if you hear someone speak in a total different language.
Do you also want to learn it? Understand it?

------------------------------------------------------------------
Mouse-click switches between:
- screen scaled image
- The large image (for printing)

Right-click: Save/Copy the image

A custom 'software based' pixel 2D/3D engine,
written in vanilla JavaScript, some more info in the source-code
- The work will refresh and restart after some time -
-------------------------------------------------

xxx amsterdam chillout ^__^
